story: NewsAlfie Evans dad says new baby has given him a reason to live after sons deathWATCH EXCLUSIVE VIDEO: Dad Tom, , says the six-month-old is the double of his brother and has helped him and his partner Kate James cope after Alfies tragic deathShareCommentsByPhil Cardy:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video father-of-alfie-evans-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe father of “right to le” shytoddler Alfie Evans cradles his new baby son and tells how the tot has given him a reason to live. Little Thomas Evans is the double of Alfie – the -month-old who died after a heartbreaking legal battle by his parents. Thomas is six months old and his dad Tom today reveals how having a new baby has brought a joy he and partner Kate James feared they would never experience again. Tom, , told the Sunday Mirror: “Thomas is Alfie’s double, the resemblance is amazing. “When we see Thomas pull a face he looks like Alfie, we feel that in a way we have them both with us.  “He’s such a happy baby, he does nothing but smile. I had a great connection with Alfie and I feel like I’ve got the same with Thomas. “We’re hanging in there, keeping sane, doing as well as we can. I wouldn’t know where I was without baby Thomas. “I’ve got something to wake up to with him. I have to keep happy for Thomas’s sake. I wouldn’t want to wake upit wasn’t for the baby. “I don’t like to think what it would be like without Thomas. I worryhe wasn’t here, where would I be  “How would I be  What would my mental health be ”   Tom was speaking as he and Kate revealed a pound, fund for Alfie will be spent on helping sick children. The proud dad added: “When Thomas gets older we want him to understand what Alfie went through and he can know good came from it. We’d like to help children around the UK and the world.” The picture of Tom and Thomas is a ray of light after two years of pain and torment. Tom and Kate had fought to keep Alfie on a le support machine in a case which drew global attention. They lost, ultimately, and their son died at Liverpool’s Alder Hey Children’s Hospital from an ultra-rare degenerative brain disease. Kate, , fell pregnant with Thomas as the legal battle – which taxed her and Tom to the limits – was played out. But the couple stayed together through those tough times and are now devoted to Thomas. Tom said: “Kate is a great mum for Thomas. She has moments when she’s upset and she has a cry. That’s what you have to do to release the emotion. Mums have that bond, especially with the first child.” He accused doctors of separating him and Kate in hospital and telling her that the legal battle was wrong. Tom went on: “It was hard. She questionedwe were doing the right thing. I told her what we were doing, what our friends and family were doing, was the right thing for Alfie. But it wasn’t easy. It was hard for her to hear the arguments of the doctors every day. There was a lot of strain, but we stayed together. “We both loved Alfie and both wanted the best for Alfie. “We remained tough. They were telling her I was wrong. She was pregnant and her hormones and emotions were all over the place.”  The arrival of Thomas triggered a wave of emotions for the couple. Tom explained: “I was nervous but felt happy. We had the test done and he didn’t have the same genes as Alfie, we were told he would be okay. “We were happy that Alfie had a brother, it’s just that Alfie wasn’t there with us. “It was hard because the first time we had a beautul boy and we lost him. “Then when we had Thomas there were tears of joy, but it felt dferent because we had lost our first boy. “We were the same parents Alfie had at home, just in a dferent position, more tense. “ We still speak about Alfie, but we don’t speak about the hospital. We talk about how he is going to help save a lot of children in the future.”  Tom tearfully told how he gave Alfie mouth-to-mouth as his le ebbed away in the early hours of April  last year. With tears rolling down his cheeks Tom said: “I think about that moment every day. That moment is forever in my head. “I was giving him mouth-to-mouth, I could hear him breathing, like a sigh. It gave me more encouragement to keep trying. The noises kept coming and coming. But Kate was saying ‘Stop it, you’re just expanding his belly’. I didn’t want to stop. But I knew he was dead. At the very last moment his colour went. “The police and doctors and nurses were looking through the door, standing there. “I said to them ‘Can’t you do anything ’ They pulled his le support out and thought he would die in three to four minutes. But he lived for five days. We put him on our knees and sang to him, cuddled him.   “I said right to the end that their treatment of him was shyinhumane. “I do feel bad for the nurses because they didn’t have the power. All they could do was stand and watch for five days while oxygen and food was withheld. Up until the last I thought we were going to save him. I tried every avenue. “I was just a dad who wanted the best for his son.” Alfie was born in May  and while initially healthy he fell seriously ill at six months old. He was in Alder Hey Hospital for the last  months of his le. Doctors found he had the rare brain condition GABA transaminase deficiency. They said there was nothing more they could do and advised that Alfie should be allowed to slip away. A court agreed – prompting Tom and Kate’s long battle to overturn the decision, in the hope that Alfie could be taken abroad for le-saving treatment. They appealed to UK and European judges and Tom even met Pope Francis, who backed the couple. But ultimately the courts ruled Alfie’s le support could be switched off. Tom said he and Kate still see grief and bereavement counsellors as they strive for the best way forward. And he is determined to stay strong. He added: “We are still understanding how to grieve. “I want to be more happy around Thomas, I don’t want him to see me crying all the time or with a bad face. “He needs a happy environment. I need to understand how to be happy.” Alfies legacy to help other seriously ill kids Alfies dad Tom says a pound, fund raised in his name will now help other seriously ill children. The sum came from an “Alfie’s Army” fundraising page set up during the legal battle to pay for potentially le-saving treatment in Italy or Poland. Hundreds of supporters also joined demonstrations in support of Alfie. The family has applied for charity status and has already provided wheelchairs and sensory equipment for disabled children. Tom said: “When we get something we think ‘Alfie bought it for them, Alfie is helping that person’. We’re happy that his name can live on in other parents’ and children’s minds.” The Alfie’s Army page states: “We don’t want any other family going through what we have... we are hoping to open a foundation to help other families get the help they need.”

title: amber peats grandmother reveals last
story: NewsAmber Peats grandmother reveals last gt tragic teen gave her before she diedEXCLUSIVE: Jenner Lancaster says her granddaughter Amber was let down by everyone before she was found hangedShareCommentsByGrace Macaskill :,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsJenner Lancaster has blasted social services in two counties for failing to help her granddaughter before her tragic death "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is the last gt her granddaughter gave her on the final day she saw her alive. And shyJenner Lancaster keeps it safe in a trinket box of memories. A Mother’s Day card from a tragic, troubled girl whose harrowing le was last week laid bare in a coroner’s court. Two years after that fleeting visit to her gran, Amber Peat was found hanged after running away from the last of the  homes her parents had moved her to. She was just . On Friday coroner Laurinda Bower ed a narrative conclusion on the youngster’s death, saying she could not be sure she intended to commit suicide. But she blasted education, health and social care agencies in two counties for missing  chances to save the tormented child. And she panned the girl’s mum and stepdad for showing “very little,any, consideration” for her welfare. “This is proof the authorities failed Amber,” says a tearful Jenner, , tenderly touching that treasured card. “She was let down by everyone. But it doesn’t change the outcome does it  Amber was a little girl crying out for help and nobody listened. How must she have been feeling in those final moments  “I’m sure she would have opened up to meshe hadn’t been forced to move away.”   The inquest heard allegations that Amber – whose body was found in woods near her home – suffered emotional abuse, and that her stepdad Danny “humiliated” her and gave her “severe punishments”. A teacher claimed the Cinderella schoolgirl told her the family’s dog was treated better than her. A policewoman told the court her mum Kelly dismissed her disappearance as just “attention seeking”. Today, her gran reveals how Kelly banned her from seeing Amber after that last visit on Mother’s Day, . Jenner’s son Adrian,  – Amber’s real dad – had split from Kelly in Christmas  after a turbulent -year relationship.  He has a conviction for domestic violence against her. “He’s no angel,” says Jenner. “But there’s no excuse for Kelly to have stopped Amber’s contact with me. It was cold and cruel. “Amber said she couldn’t stay long that day as her mum and Danny were waiting in the car. “I texted Kelly a couple of weeks later to askI could see her. I got a reply saying she wasn’t sure, then the whole family just up and left. When I called Kelly’s number she’d changed it. Her old neighbours had no idea where they’d gone. My heart was broken. “Amber was so loving. She spent weekends with me and every time she went home she’d leave notes saying things like ‘love you, Nanna’.”  Jenner was at the inquest every day, hoping to make sense of what happened. “I owed it to Amber,” she says. Nottingham Coroner’s Court heard how Amber had moved house “no less than  times” around Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire. And social services in Derbyshire were already involved with the Peat family when they moved to Mansfield, Notts, in . When Amber started the local Queen Elizabeth school, staff there quickly grew worried. She told teachers her stepdad Danny would wake her at .pm to clean floors for two hours as punishment for failing to do chores. She said he made her wear baggy grey jogging bottoms to school and carry her belongings in a plastic bag instead of a satchel or backpack to humiliate her. He denied it. Form teacher Rebecca Beard told the inquest: “Amber said her dad wanted to get everyone to laugh at her.” The distraught schoolgirl told another teacher – after briefly running away from home in April  – that the family dog was treated better than her.  Six months before her death she wrapped a school tie around her neck and told pupils: “I hate my le. I want to kill myself.” Teachers twice tipped off Nottinghamshire social workers but were told that her case did not “cross the threshold” for intervention. Coroner Bower said Amber’s tragic death highlighted the lack of sharing of information between agencies in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire. She said: “No one got to the point of how Amber was feeling because there was not that support in place.” Amber, who had two siblings, was found dead in June  after a row over cleaning a cool box after a family holiday in Cornwall. It was almost eight hours before Kelly, , and Danny, , reported her missing, after going shopping, out for dinner and to a carwash. Both denied all the allegations made at the inquest.  Now Jenner, who lives in Nottinghamshire, is left with that trinket box and a conviction that more could have been done to save her granddaughter. “How could Amber’s cries for help have gone unheard ” she says. “People will say ‘lessons have been learned’ but it won’t bring her back.” She is surrounded by pictures of Amber – as a baby, as a three-year-old playing by a duck pond, as a young girl nearing teens, posing elegantly. Jenner shows me a Christmas decoration Amber made from lollipop sticks. All the time she holds a green stone keyring Amber gave her. “It’s only a cheap thing she won at a fair, but it means everything to me. It’s one of the few things I have left of her.” Jenner says. Amber harboured dreams of being a model. “She loved having her picture taken and every time she came she’d get my make-up out to do herself up.”  But the vulnerable girl also yearned for her lost childhood. A youth worker who had sessions with Amber told the inquest her mother “laughed” at a letter her vulnerable daughter wrote saying she just wanted to be a little girl again. After the inquest verdict on Friday, Kelly said she had been had been “the best parent” she could. Jenner says: “Amber did everything she could to get help. She spoke to teachers, wrote to her mum, had youth worker sessions yet despite all of this a house move meant she fell off the radar.” All Jenner has left now is the memory of that last big hug before Amber left that Mother’s Day, out of her le forever. “I think about her from when I wake until I close my eyes. I have happy dreams in which I believe she comes to visit me. “I like to think it means Amber is finally at peace.” Scandal of lost chancesJan : Amber referred to Derbyshire social services by family’s GP. She runs away from home twice. No family assessment done. June : The Peats move to Notts. Amber’s file is not passed on. March : Amber’s school in Mansfield contacts Nottingham County Council over teacher’s concerns she is being emotionally abused and deprived of food. Social services took no action. May : Amber missing. Mum and stepdad fail to report it for eight hours, going out to eat instead. June , : Her body is found hanged in a bush.

title: brave girl who worlds youngest
story: NewsBrave girl who was worlds youngest heart op baby at minutes old turns fiveEXCLUSIVE: Chanel Murrish has defied all odds to make it to her fth birthday after surviving open heart surgery when she was just minutes oldShareCommentsByMichelle Rawlins:,  FEB NewsChanel entered the Guinness Book of Records after her le-saving surgery "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCourageous Chanel shyMurrish poses with her birthday cake and pink balloon in an image her parents thought they might never see. Chanel is five today and has defied all the odds to be here at all. She made history as the youngest child in the world to have open heart surgery – MINUTES after being born. Doctors had given her just a five per cent chance of survival. Mum Fay, , says: “We had been told there was little chance of our daughter making it and were twice offered a termination. “But look at her now – Chanel’s proved over and over again what a little miracle she is. We still have to pinch ourselves that she is here and doing as well as she is. It’s like a dream come true that Chanel is celebrating her fth birthday.”  The youngster is spending today with family and friends at a kids’ play centre with a special guest appearance from her idol – Disney character Rapunzel. And she has been looking forward to that, telling the Sunday Mirror: “I’m excited that I will be five. I’m going to have a cake and a princess party with all my friends and play in the ball pit.” Proud Fay, from Seaham, County Durham, adds: “To see our little girl running around, doing what other five-year-olds do, is amazing. I’ve lost count of how many times we nearly lost her, so to see her so happy and healthy is the greatest gt we could ask for.” Chanel entered the Guinness Book of Records after her lesaving surgery moments after birth – and has had  operations.  She has survived a cardiac arrest, a stroke that resulted in cerebral palsy and a le-threatening seizure that has left her with epilepsy. Fay was  weeks into her pregnancy when she and HGV driver husband, Michael, , were told Chanel had hypoplastic left heart syndrome. It means the left ventricle in her heart is severely underdeveloped and only half of children with the condition reach the age of five. A further complication emerged before Chanel was born – intact atrial septum was weakening her tiny heart even further.  Doctors asked Fay and Michael whether they wanted a termination. But Fay, who also has two sons – Chase, nine, and Cole, six – said No. The clincher came during a scan on which Chanel seemed to give a thumbs-up. Fay recalls: “I could feel her kicking and I was sure it was her way of saying ‘I can do this, don’t give up’.” Chanel was born by Caesarean in February  in a cardiac operating theatre at the Freeman Hospital, Newcastle. Surgeons were ready to operate immediately. Stay-at-home mum Fay says: “I didn’t even get chance to hold my little girl before she was whisked away and her chest opened up in an adjoining theatre.  “It was touch-and-go and specialists warned us there was a very high chance Chanel wouldn’t make it through the surgery. And evenshe did she may never leave hospital and would eventually need a heart transplant. “Although terried, I refused to dwell on the negatives and kept telling myself my tiny little fighter was going to make it.” Which is exactly what Chanel did – and she is now the oldest known British survivor with her two conditions. She has endured open heart surgery another three times, surviving a cardiac arrest after the second procedure when she was just seven days old. Chanel was so heavily sedated that it was only when she came home that it emerged she had suffered a stroke and couldn’t move the left side of her body. It left Chanel unable to walk until she was two-and-a-half and she still wears a splint on her left leg. She now needs  doses of medication daily to prevent heart failure, prevent blood clotting and to manage her epilepsy.  She is tube fed through her tummy and has liver and kidney problems due to the lack of oxygen circulating around her body. And Fay, seen right with a Pride of Britain special recognition award for fundraising to help other sick children, knows Chanel will fall ill again. But she and Michael give her every opportunity to lead as normal a le as possible. She adds: “At some point she will go into heart failure or suffer another cardiac arrest and will need an urgent heart transplant. It could be tomorrow – it could be  years. We have no idea. “Before Chanel’s last open-heart surgery in August , she was so weak she could only walk a couple of steps and couldn’t even finish a full sentence without gasping for breath.  “Her lips were permanently purple and she spent weeks just lying on the couch with no energy whatsoever. But since the surgery, she is like a dferent child. “Chanel started mainstream school last September, and although she only manages mornings, she loves nothing more than playing with her friends and gets up every morning full of beans. “Chanel has constant one-to-one support enabling her to go to school, which is an absolute blessing after everything she has been through. “We are acutely aware that every day with her is incredibly precious. We have no idea what the future holds. “So as Chanel celebrates her birthday, we count our blessings in awe of her feisty spirit and sheer determination – and look forward to what the future holds.”

story: NewsopinionBritains richest man could end homelessness - instead hes moving abroadJim Ratclfe is moving to Monaco - this perfectly legal operation will cost the Treasury at least £million, cash that would end the scandal of people living on the streetsShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  FEB NewsopinionThe homeless suffer in our cities while Jim Ratclfe has raced to move his assets offshore "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is a tale of two shyBritains,  style, lost in the vicious clamour over Brexit. story: NewsEastEnders Tanya Franks running London marathon for ailing Barbara WindsorActress Tanya Franks, who plays Rainie Cross, has pledged to run for Dame Barbara Windsor and her own stepdadShareCommentsByJanine Yaqoob:,  FEB NewsActress Tanya Franks, who plays Rainie Cross, has pledged to run for Dame Barbara Windsor and her own stepdad"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email EastEnders ’ Tanya Franks will run the London Marathon after being inspired by TWO people battling Alzheimer’s.The -year-old actress has seen former co-star Dame Barbara Windsor tackle dementia with dignity and courage. Training for the event has kept Tanya occupied while not playing TV’s Rainie. She and her character could barely be more dferent. Rainie is a former druggie and Tanya is teetotal and enjoys a quiet le with her partner James Barriscale in Kent. Her powerful performances as Rainie have touched families who have been ravaged by addiction. “Somebody recently came up to me in the street and said a family member of theirs had been going through a similar situation,” she told.  “As a family they’ve clocked into Rainie and over the years she’s been a formative character for them. Particularly when she was going through the crack addiction. Their family member was going through the same thing and they would watch Rainie. We have a social responsibility to tell the stories.” Tanya first set foot in Albert Square more than  years ago and loves every minute. The London-born star – who was seen last week at the West End version of Only Fools And Horses – had a special word to say about another EastEnders veteran, -year-old June Brown, who plays Dot Cotton. Tanya said: “June is wonderful. She’s still playing that iconic character. She comes on set with all the same ethics she’s ever had. Her integrity towards the work is absolutely paramount. She’s an inspiration to me and it’s an honour to work with her.” And Tanya also heaped praise on another inspirational actress – Olivia Colman, , who played Queen Anne in The Favourite and is up for the best actress award at tonight’s Oscars. The pair starred in Broadchurch together.   Tanya said: “I watched the filmwhen I was in LA. She’s amazing in it. I was mesmerised by her. I sent her a message straight after. “She’s not a showbiz person. She’s down to earth and fantastic at her job. It’s fantastic she’s being recognised. It’s encouraging as it reminds you it’s possible and that dreams do come true.” But Tanya doesn’t have any visions of Hollywood stardom herself. She added: “Rainie challenges me right across the gamut. There’s drama and comedy. I’m learning from her. If Rainie keeps challenging me like this I’m happy to stay.”To support the Barbaras Revolutionairies Alzheimers London Marathon team, click here .Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at webcelebs@trinitymirror or call us direct   .

title: five top tips keep your
story: NewsFive top tips to keep your brain younger for longer from new diet to exerciseYour brain can be healthy and active no matter what your ageyou follow these five science-backed pointersShareCommentsByKelly JenkinsAntonia Paget:,  FEB NewsThere are ways you can keep your brain younger for longer "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailForgotten where you put your mobile, feeling overwhelmed by a to-do list – or simply swamped with information  You are not alone. For as we age, our brains slow down – and by  our capacity to know and recognise is beginning to slip. With each year that passes, areas of the brain involved in memory, attention and shyperception start to shrink and no longer communicate with one another as efficiently. And this causes problems with memory and concentration. But the good news is there are many ways to help keep your brain younger for longer – and it is never too late to start. Here we look at five of the best science-backed methods to keep your brain young, healthy and highly ing.   Take up a new exerciseResearchers at Australia’s University of Canberra found that regular aerobic exercise dramatically improved cognitive abilities such as thinking, reading, learning and reasoning.Studies at the University of Edinburgh also found people doing more physical activity had less brain shrinkage. Even those who have done little exercise before the age of  can enjoy the benefits almost immediately.  Imaging studies also found new activities exercise large parts of the brain’s cortex and increase levels of activity in several areas. This activity decreases when the task becomes automatic and shyroutine. So change things here and there. Have a shower at a dferent time, watch a dferent news story, or go for a walk. Take up an instrument Learning to play a musical instrument not only boosts creativity and the ability to focus, it can lower the risk of dementia and cognitive impairment by more than a third, says a study at the University of Calornia. Flex your mental muscle Your brain is just like any other muscle, so give it a good workout and it will stay strong. Brain-training puzzles and apps such as those made by Peak Games have been scientically proven to increase cognition and everyday ing. A new study of  adults, shyconducted at the City University of New York, showed that those who used brain-training apps regularly for eight weeks had increased mental cognition. Michael Merzenich, a neuroscientist at the University of Calornia, San Francisco, has developed a computer-based training regimen to speed up how the brain processes information.The Brain Fitness Program works with language and hearing to improve speed and accuracy. It starts by asking you to shydistinguish between sounds, such as dog and bog, at an increasingly faster rate. Merzenich likens it to a tennis coach firing balls at you faster and faster over the course of the summer to keep you challenged. Brain-boost your diet The Global Council on Brain Health revealed in  that what is good for your heart is good for your brain. This means a diet rich in berries, leafy greens, olive oils, nuts and seeds. Fruit, low-fat dairy, poultry and grains are also good. A list of what to avoid includes fried foods, pastries, red meat and salt.   Memory mineralsStudies at King’s College, London , and the University of Rochester in New York showed a low iron intake can have a bad effect on IQ levels and cognitive .A lack of iron causes low haemoglobin levels, which affect the supply of oxygen to the brain. An iron-rich drink such as Spatone can replace iron missing from the diet. Deficiency of zinc, found in peanuts, shellfish and whole grains, can also interfere with memory. Taking a supplement of -mg daily can help.

story: NewsGolden retriever and girl, , with Downs syndrome become friends for leFrom helping to put her coat on to giving soothing "head rests", Emma the dog has improved Millis quality of leShareCommentsByMatthew Barbour:,  FEB NewsMilli with her loyal canine friend Emma who acts as her support dog "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGolden retriever Emma has made herself a Friend for Le… as support dog to Milli Gunn, who has Down’s. Emma’s specialist training enables her to carry out a range of tasks for the eight-year-old — she is even shylearning to help her get her coat on. And the loyal helper has now been named a finalist in the Friends for Le competition at next month’s Crufts. Emma, who landed her role through the charity Dogs for Good, can also hunt out Milli’s medicated drinks when she loses them — and gives soothing “head rests” when the youngster gets out of breath and anxious. As well as Down’s syndrome, Milli has a serious heart condition and has already had open heart surgery twice, the first time at just four months.   Dad Steve, , and mum Christina, , a teacher, found Dogs for Good while researching what help was shyout there for children with disabilities. The charity is the first UK assistance dog organisation to give aid to youngsters like Milli. Steve, of Upminster, Essex, said: “It’s like Emma turned a light on for Milli and has given her the confidence to shine as brightly in the wider world as she does at home. “At her sister’s recent Pony Club awards ceremony, I was amazed to see Milli chatting to people and shyintroducing her to ‘my Emma’. “Prior to getting Emma she would have been very quiet and not wanted to interact at all.” He said after first being introduced to Emma by the charity, Milli had told him: “I liked that dog, Daddy. She’s fluffy and lovely.”  Hairdresser Steve added: “As far as I was concerned that was it – the seal of approval. “As soon as Milli is home from school she piles in for a big cuddle with Emma and spends lots of time talking to her and stroking her, which really helps to bring down her anxiety.” Emma has now been with the family for just over a year. title: mum gives birth twins 100
story: NewsMum gives birth to twins  miles apart in horrendous and confusing ordealThe woman, who was -weeks pregnant, was rushed between maternity wards in Wick and Inverness after her waters had brokenShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  FEB NewsIt was decided to move her to Raigmore Hospital in Inverness,  miles away "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum gave birth to her premature twins in two dferent hospitals  miles apart in a horrendous and confusing ordeal. The -week pregnant woman gave birth to two little boys, who have dferent birthdays, in a journey that involved a number of ambulances, police cars and a helicopter.After her waters broke  weeks early while she was at work in November, the mum was initially taken toCaithness General Hospital, in Wick.But it was decided to move her to Raigmore Hospital in Inverness,  miles away, reports the Mail Online.Halfway through the journey, the ambulance made an emergency stop and she gave birth to her first son atGolspie Hospital in Sutherland. He was born breech, which is buttocks first, at around .pm. The mum was told that an air ambulance had been called however it would be a while until it arrived. During this time, the mum described the moment before she was sent away as being filled with confusion, questions and lack of decisions. A doctor and two nurses eventually arrived by police car from Inverness to take care of the first twin. As she waited on the air ambulance to take her away, the mum was told that it was unable to land due to frost on the propellers.   Because of this, a decision was made to continue the ambulance trip to Inverness. Two ambulances and three cars left at am the next day. When the mum and medical convoy finally arrived at Inverness the second twin was induced.The mother wrote in a Facebook post: We left for Inverness by convoy, two ambulances, one with me and two midwives and the other with twin one and two nurses, a police car and two other cars with doctors and my partner.When we arrived in Inverness I was induced and twin two was born. He was taken to the special care baby unit along with his brother. She added: ‘But we would like to know why weren’t we flown to Inverness  Why could specialists not come up to Wick  Why are Wick and Golspie staff expected to work like that  Golspie wasn’t prepared for such an emergency but they did what they could and they did amazing. This shouldn’t be the case. We dread to think what could have happenedthe road was closed by an accident or bad weather. The mum and her twins stayed in hospital for six weeks until they were sent home.   NHS Highland say that they they will examine how the case was handled after it was raised at Holyrood by Highlands and Islands Labour MSP Rhoda Grant. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon also pledged to look into the -mile ambulance journey. Ron Gunn of the Caithness Health Action Team , which is campaigning for better maternity services, described the case as horrendous.He told the Mail Online: Valid questions need answered. The whole thing would have been avoidedthey had airlted her down to Inverness or they had brought up a team to deal with it in Wick.Hopefully lessons can be learned from it. We will probably never get back to where we were but the system we have at the moment is not really safe. A NHS Highland spokesman told ious publications safety of mum and children was the first priority of the health board and that standard assessment, triage and transfer protocols were followed. The spokesman said: For reasons of patient confidentiality, NHS Highland would not wish to comment publicly upon the case in question but as in all such cases we will be conducting an internal review to consider the specic circumstances of this case. Whenever these contingency plans have been implemented, there has been a good outcome for mothers and babies. Predicting how labour will progress is a matter of clinical judgement and it is not always easy to predict. NHS Highland does everything it can to make sure that the best possible clinical advice is obtained before deciding on how best to proceed.

title: mum too young smear test
story: NewsMum-to-be too young for smear test despite having abnormal cells on cervixDemi Ablett, , from Newquay wants to share her story to make sure young women or teenagers do not experience what she has gone throughShareCommentsByCharlotte Becquart:,  FEB NewsDemi Ablett, of Newquay, has been diagnosed with CIN  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum-to-be has been told shes too young for a smear test - despite having abnormal cells on her cervix .Demi Ablett, who is expecting her first baby in July, was diagnosed with CIN  which means theres a moderate chance the cells on the gateway to her womb will become cancerous.But despite this she cannot have a cervical screening and is now speaking out about how important they are, reports Plymouth Live . The -year-old, fromNewquay, initially went to her doctor with fatigue and heavy bleeding after an abortion in  aged , but claims she was misdiagnosed as having an abnormal period.  Demi explained: “At first I was misdiagnosed. They said that it was abnormal period and thought it would be sorted with contraception. “After  months, I found out I had CIN  and have been struggling with it since.” CIN  is caused by human papillomavirusand treatment to remove them is usually recommended. Demi was diagnosed aged  and she has not been able to have a smear test since. She said: “I saw a gynaecologist, who immediately booked me in for an operation to remove pre-cancerous cells. “I’ve been going back and forth from the hospital, having procedures. “In the last four years I’ve been on three tablets a day for two years, biopsies nearly every month, three procedures on my cervix where they removed the pre-cancerous and cancerous cells.”  The minimum age to get a cervical screening in the UK is currently , and is justied by the fact that cervical cancer is very rare below that age and that it is common to have abnormalities which usually go away by themselves. Due to the dferent operations that Demi has had over the years, she was told that there was a high chance that she could not have a child. She explained: “For the last two years I have massively struggled due to the fact I was advised I may not be able to conceive and thatthe speed and continuous spreading carried on a hysterectomy would be on the cards. “I am now nearly  weeks pregnant but in those  weeks I’ve had a trip to Treliske every two weeks to check my cervix , midwe appointments nearly every two weeks, consultation appointments and prenatal appointments. “It’s going well but I have to go to the hospital every week. The operations were to remove parts of the cervix and that’s what made it dficult. My cervix is too short. I could have had a premature baby, a miscarriage, etc.”   She said that she wants to share her story to make sure young women or teenagers do not experience what she has gone through. “I’m , still not the legal age for a smear but yet have suffered massively and my family have as well seeing me go through this,” she said. “I need to try and tell my story because more woman need to realise a smear isn’t the scary bit - it’s what can happen after. “The minimum age should be lowered orgirls go to the doctor and ask, they should be offered the test. “Both of my younger sisters have been to the doctor’s as soon as they were  due to all the complications that I’ve had. “You just have to push and push. When you’re a teenager you know your body. If it doesn’t seem right, you have to ask to be tested.” Demi is a tattoo model and she says she uses her photo shoots for magazines to raise awareness as much as she can and do campaigns.  She said: “Smear tests should be offered earlier and it’s about getting more girls to do it. “I raise awareness any way I can. We’ve got to help each other when it comes to smear test and cervical cancer. “Hospital staff is amazing, everyone is so, so good and they are mostly women so they understand what you’re going through. I’ve found that taking my mother and my grandmother helps.” In , ministers rejected calls for the screening age for cervical cancer to be lowered, arguing that doing so would cause  positive results and would lead to people receiving unnecessary – and potentially harmful – treatment. According to the NHS, the symptoms of cervical cancer are unusual vaginal bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, pain during sex, unusual vaginal discharge and pain in the lower back or pelvis. Most cases of cervical cancer are caused by the human papillomavirus , and there are effective vaccines that can protect people from contracting HPV. The vaccines, however, cannot treat existing infections.

title: mum who kept miscarrying solved
story: NewsMum who kept miscarrying solved problem herself by watching pregnant cowsLowri Jones, from Llangwm, Conwy, lost five babies - including twins - but a TV programme on cattle changed her leShareCommentsByKelly Williams:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video lowri-jones-calls-for-support-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum claims a farming programme about pregnant cows helped her conceive after suffering four miscarriages.Lowri Jones said she tried to tell doctors she knew something wasnt right when her energy levels plummeted as soon as she fell pregnant following the birth of her first son in .She went on to lose five babies, including twins but was just told she needed God on her side, reports North Wales Live .It wasnt until the mum from Llangwm, Conwy was watching a SC show, Ffermio about chemical iodine imbalances in cattle that made her suspect that was what was wrong with her.   She said: I tried to tell doctors that something wasnt right. Obviously Id had a successful pregnancy with my first son but after that, every pregnancy afterwards left me with no energy at all, I was so ill. But after suffering my fourth miscarriage - the last while I was carrying twins - I was just told I needed God on my side and to just keep trying. She added: One night, I was sitting on couch watching a Welsh farming programme when the vet, Cen Williams was talking about how he had noticed more dead calves than usual.   The ones that were born alive were very lethargic and were taking a long time to get up. The vet said it was because of a lack of iodine in the soil which had been washed away due to the rain. This had caused thyroid problems in cows. I knew I had a thyroid problem and it wasnt being monitored well enough. The cows were given an iodine and thyroxine boost and were much better and more calves were being born alive. I sat up and thought thats whats wrong with me.   The programme spurred Lowri to seek fresh medical help and demand further tests. She also took to the internet to carry out her own research and started cooking with a special salt containing iodine. Her determination saw her referred to a thyoid specialist and she was given thyroxine every two weeks when she fell pregnant with her second son, Gwil who was born in . Lowri added: Falling pregnant wasnt the problem for me, it was keeping the baby that was the issue, but once I started having thyroxine, I was full of le and felt so much better.  I just knew that pregnancy would go full term. I honestly thinkI hadnt seen the programme, Gwil wouldnt be here today. God knows how many more miscarriages I would have had. Now Lowri feels that more should be done to help couples who suffer repeated miscarriages and is calling for support from the Welsh Government. The young peoples mentor for the homeless prevention team, Gorwel within Grwp Cynefin said: The more I got angry and demanded tests, the more they were listening, but it shouldnt have to be that way.   Im a strong believer that you know your own body and I knew I wasnt just feeling tired because of the pregnancies, there was more to it than that. But why did I have to lose five babies before being sent for tests when all of this could have been prevented  I also think there needs to be somewhere for people to talk about miscarriage. My first was a nightmare, I was in bed for three days, I bled heavily and nobody phoned to check up on me.   By the time Id gone through it four times, I gave up my job as a high school pupils mentor in Ruthin because of my mental state. I was on a hamster wheel of getting pregnant, miscarrying and going back to work. I didnt really have time to grieve in three years. When Gwil arrived, I couldnt bare to leave him so I took on a house restoration project and it was the best thing I ever did. I recharged my batteries, had some me time, time to think and time to grieve and now Im back in a job I enjoy that makes me appreciate what Ive got.

story: NewsPensioner who dedicated le to WW crash victims s to memorial after fly-pastSheffield OAP Tony Foulds was back at the memorial after thousands turned out to watch the fly-past held to honour the victims of the  crashShareCommentsByDave Higgens:,  FEB NewsTony maintains a memorial for the crew "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSheffield pensioner Tony Foulds ed to the memorial for  men killed in a WW plane crash the day after an RAF fly-past took place to honour the crew. Yesterday the -year-olds dream came true after warplanes from Britain and the United States staged a fly-past to honour the th anniversary of the crash, which happened in . Tony was just eight-years-old when he witnessed the fatal crash in Endclfe Park in Sheffield, as the pilots attempted to steer clear of him and his friends. He has been diligently maintaining a memorial for the crew of the B- Flying Fortress, known as Mi Amigo, which sits in the same park. And following yesterdays emotional fly-past, the pensioner today travelled his usual seven miles, on foot and by bus, from his home to the memorial.  However, any plans the -year-old had to perform any essential maintenance to the memorial on the crash site, where he spends six days a week, were dashed by a constant stream of well-wishers hugging him, shaking his hand and asking for selfies as they congratulated him on Fridays spectacular event. Many of those stopping to talk to Mr Foulds in the Saturday sunshine echoed growing calls for the pensioner to be honoured by the Queen for his dedication to the Mi Amigos crew. Mr Foulds was eight when the badly-damaged bomber limped over the roofs of nearby houses and crashed into a wooded area, apparently to avoid him and his friends who were fighting on the grass. He has since dedicated his le to the crew, believing he was responsible for their deaths. However, scores of people who stopped to talk to him on Saturday morning urged him to stop feeling guilty.One elderly man said to Mr Foulds: You need to stop this talk of feeling guilty.   It was the Germans who killed those men, not you. You were a kid. It wasnt your fault. Another shook him briskly by the hand and said: You deserve a knighthood. Itll be travestythey dont give you one. Mr Foulds said: Its just amazing. Theyve not stopped just coming up and shaking my hand. I had a letter from an American this morning. It said this proves what weve always thought, that you Brits do love us. The flypast, which included fighters from the United States Air Force and the RAF, was broadcast around the world and watched by a massive crowd in the park which has been estimated at , people.  Clear skies meant that the assembled audience were able to perfectly see the tribute to the men, who were limping back from a bombing raid in Denmark on the day of the fateful crash. Mr Foulds broke down in tears after the names of the dead men were read out at the salute. The event to mark the th anniversary of the crash followed a campaign by BBC Breakfasts Dan Walker, who bumped into Mr Foulds while walking his dog in the park last month. Walker, who is currently in Tanzania preparing to climb Mount Kilimanjaro for Comic Relief, is now leading the calls for the pensioner to be officially recognised.He posted on Twitter : The next step is getting Tony an honour from the Queen. title: rachael bletchly teach kids make
story: NewsopinionRachael Bletchly: Teach kids to make do and mend  ""Seams" like a top ideaMPs have the right idea — its high time we stopped buying new clothes and remembered the value of the sewing kitShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  FEB NewsopinionChildren should be taught the skills that will encourage them not to chuck clothing away but mend them instead "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’ve got a sewing kit in my drawer at work and it feels like I’m the shyoffice seamstress. Colleagues come over with missing shybuttons, split trousers and droopy hems. I once darned the boss’s cashmere jumper so he wouldn’t chuck it out. Because I learned to stitch and sew at my mother’s knee. She was a child of the Second World War when Britain was taught how to Make Do And Mend. Clothing was rationed so shyfactories and workers were free to make unorms. The government issued a booklet advising housewives, school kids and Boy Scouts how to repair and revive worn-out togs.   And a cartoon character called Mrs Sew and Sew gave handy tips on shyturning collars, darning socks, fixing moth holes and even making undies out of off-ration “butter muslin”. I still have the wartime thimble my gran, mum and aunts used, and remember being taught the slogan “a neat darn is a real badge of honour”. So I’m heartened that MPs are urging schools to start teaching kids “the joy” of mending again, to tackle the environmental damage caused by “fast fashion”. One million tons of clothing are thrown away every year in the UK, with , tons going to landfill or incineration. High street brands and online stores selling pound T-shirts and dresses for a fiver mean some items are worn once then binned.   And each year the average Brit buys a full suitcase-worth of new shyshygear — more than anywhere  in Europe. The Commons environmental audit committee has called for a p levy on every item of clothing sold, to raise poundmillion a year for shycollection and recycling. But MPs also want lessons in school on “designing, creating, mending and repairing clothes”. They think it will also give shyanxious teens a creative outlet.   Mary Creagh, the Labour chair, said: “Fashion shouldn’t cost the earth. Our insatiable appetite for clothes comes with a huge social and shyenvironmental price tag. “Children should be taught the joy of making and mending clothes in school as an antidote to anxiety and the mental health crisis. “And consumers must play their part by buying less, mending, renting and sharing more.” It’s a darn good idea.

title: saira khan keeping shamima begum
story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Keeping Shamima Begum with baby could help make her better personShe’s seen a great deal of brutality and pain butshe reconnects with love she might just begin to see where she went wrongShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  FEB NewsopinionShamima Begum "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe political wrangling over ISIS bride Shamima Begum rumbles on as ious countries – including ours – queue up to disown her.I’ve already said that I believe she’s a danger to Britain and should not be allowed back,that’s legally possible.However, at the centre of this sorry mess is a helpless newborn son, who is British by birth. And Shamima’s family are now asking for him to be brought to Britain while she stays in a Syrian refugee camp awaiting her fate. Shamima’s sister Renu has appealed for Home Secretary Sajid Javid’s help to get him into the UK, describing her nephew as “the one true innocent in this debacle”. Well, she’s half right. The baby clearly IS an innocent, but so are all the children brutally murdered by the vile death cult Shamima still admires – including ones killed in Manchester by the suicide bombing that she justied as “retaliation”.   As mothers go, she’s not a great prospect. So the question now is, should this baby be separated from her and raised by her family  Those who back this course of action say the baby will have a better start in le in the UK. Well, he’ll clearly be in a healthier environment, but key for me is that he would be without his mother. And we should never underestimate the trauma babies can suffer when separated from mothers. I speak as someone who adopted a baby from an orphanage when she was days old. My daughter Amara was abandoned by her birth mother so she never had a choice. For now, she’s a happy, healthy, entirely normal seven-year-old. But what I was told by the experts overseeing our adoption about the damage done to such babies was deeply worrying.   It was made very clear that no matter how secure and loving our home, a child separated from its birth mother will grow up with a sense of loss and with questions we will have to answer one day. Every parent who adopts a child needs to be prepared to provide the right information, delivered using the right language. They also need to know when to get professional help. The research is pretty clear. Myron Hofer, developmental psychology director at New York’s Columbia University, found early separation can “contribute to a complex, changing pattern of vulnerability over the le span”. So unless Shamima’s baby is in immediate danger, he should stay with her. Poverty and displacement are endured by many in this world who survive because they have family around them. We can’t take away kids based on our personal views. Otherwise we’d put them in care because the parents think homosexuality is a sin, or that hanging should be brought back. This child is Shamima’s best chance of wanting to change. As a mum, I know that a child can help you become a better person. At , she’s seen a great deal of brutality and pain. Soshe reconnects with love and compassion she might just begin to see where she went wrong.

title: worried mum begs doctors give
story: NewsWorried mum begs doctors to give -stone son gastric bypass at  years oldEXCLUSIVE: Donna Rawlins is convinced her son should have a £, gastric bypass on the NHS after she had one doneShareCommentsByGeraldine McKelvieJack Falber:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDonna Rawlins says she thinks her st son Ben should have a gastric bypass like she did "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMum Donna Rawlins blames herself for letting her -year-old son Ben become obese. At  stone, three pounds, he is more than twice the average weight for his age after scoffing mountains of junk food. Now his mum is begging doctors to give him a pound, NHS gastric bypass. That is because Donna — who herself once weighed  stone — had the same operation last year. The -year-old ambulance worker said the procedure helped her to shed st and she now weighs less than her son. “People might criticise me for wanting to put my child through major surgery but I know from my own experience that it will change his le,” she said. During the procedure, the top part of the stomach is joined to the small intestine, so you feel fuller soon and you don’t absorb as many calories through food.   Ben, who is ft in tall, is bullied over his weight and lacks the willpower to diet. He said: “The bullying makes me feel bad. I want a gastric bypass like my mum. “Even though it would take a while to recover, I think it would be worth it and I could go on my bike with my friends.” Donna, from Havant, Hants, said: “I’ve broken down in tears in the doctor’s surgery because he really needs help. “A gastric bypass is major surgery but will be worth it. “Willpower is a big problem with Ben. He’s asked for slimming shakes but they’ll leave him hungry and he’ll give up. “If I could turn back time, I wouldn’t have let him eat so much junk. “I always apologise to him for letting him become the way he is as I blame myself.   “I’ve tried to push him into rugby and football but he would rather come home and play the Xbox.” Ben ate normally until he was four when Donna split with his dad and he started to have tantrumsshe didn’t ply him with chips, pasta and biscuits. “He would lob the plate across the roomhe didn’t like what was on there,” she said. “He was a chicken nugget machine. I would only give him about four at first. As he got older, his appetite would increase and he was always saying he was hungry. “I tried giving him smaller portions but half an hour later, he’d be raiding the cupboards for biscuits. I do wish I hadn’t given in now.”   She added: “I’ve been told I need to cut things down and be strict with him but he has behavioural issues and I need a house left standing. “I can’t constantly be decorating because he is lobbing a plate across the room. “He has all the signs of ADHD including poor concentration but he’s never been diagnosed. “I’m always being told it’s a parenting issue. I ask myselfI’m a bad parent. But I always come down on him like a ton of bricks over right and wrong.” Bullies teased Ben when they saw his mum at the school gates. Donna explained: “Ben was coming home upset as he was being taunted. People would say, ‘You are getting as fat as your mum’.   “It would destroy me. Some nights, I’d sit here in tears but I would use food as a comfort and he picked up on it. She could munch her way through  bags of crisps after a huge helping of pasta and chips. “I would watch telly nibbling crisps to try to make myself feel happier and he’d say, ‘You do it mum, why can’t I ’” Donna was  stone by the time she was  — and being bullied made her eat more. She said: “I was always called ‘fat cow’ walking down the road, and told boys would never have me because I’m fat. “I was terrible for eating in secret. I’d stuff my face silly at mates’ houses so my mum wouldn’t know.” At , when she fell pregnant with Ben, she was so heavy her st scales couldn’t hold her weight. Donna tried the Atkins Diet, which saw her shed st, but doctors warned it was affecting her kidneys.   She said: “I starved myself for a week once because I was so sick of Ben being bullied but I had no energy and I was no good for him. Stuck at st, she asked seven doctors to refer her for a gastric bypass before she was finally accepted last April. The op has left her feeling “ecstatic”. “I woke up from the operation and, for the first time ever, I had no interest in food,” she said. “The weight started falling off. People I’ve known for years don’t recognise me in the street. “Now, I’m stuffedI eat a Weetabix so I know it would be a godsend for Ben. I’ve been asking doctors to give him the operation for two years. “I don’t want him getting diabetes, or heart disease. But most of all I just don’t want him to have the miserable le I had for years.” Ben wants to join the police or the army when he leaves school and Donna believes the op would encourage him to be more active. She said: “He can’t join the police or the armyhe can’t run. “If I can get him down weight wise, he will enjoy sport more and won’t have kids taking the mickey and running round the pitch like a lump of lard. “I still give him treats, like a bag of popcorn on a Friday night, but I ration them.”   On a typical day, Ben’s breakfast is Weetabix, toast and scrambled eggs. Lunch is a ham sandwich and dinner spaghetti bolognese or pasta bake with chips. He no longer snacks through ten biscuits, a bowl of ice cream and a big bag of microwave popcorn each day. Tam Fry, from the National Obesity Forum, said the NHS gave children weight loss surgery onlytheir conditions were le threatening. “The child’s mum has done very well to lose this weight but it is not a good idea for the child to have bariatric surgery,” he said. “A child is still growing andyou have a gastric bypass you are severely limiting the food which that child needs in order to grow. “People might say it’s better to be thin and small but the body should be allowed to grow to its full, natural size. “The mother should hang off for a few years, all the time doing her utmost to keep him off the junk food he has been eating. “He will also need psychiatric counselling because the child has eaten too much fast food all of his le and will have a yearning to continue after a gastric bypass. “That will be ruinous because it might upset the bypass. He is not of an age to appreciate how crucial it is that he should amend his lestyle. “It’s less likely he’ll have the mental capacity to moderate his eating practices.”   Kids getting fat busting surgery at  Obese children as young as  are undergoing weight-loss surgery on the NHS. Latest stats from NHS Digital show  overweight youngsters under the age of  were operated on at hospitals in England in the three years to April . Among them were two -year-olds, five aged  and seven aged . The ops, called bariatric surgery, involve reducing stomach size, bypassing it or installing gastric bands so people eat less. A record ,-plus kids aged  to  are severely obese, one in , according to Public Health England. Tam Fry, spokesman for the National Obesity Forum, said: “There are children who are so fat that when they go to bed they roll over and lie on their airways and suffocate. “It is obese kids with le-threatening conditions like this who are having bariatric surgery. “Normally children of that age will not be given bariatric surgery because they are still growing. But in emergency cases, it does happen.”
