A spokesperson for American Airlines told : American Airlines Flight  from Maurice Bishop International Airport in Grenada to Miami International Airport encountered turbulence during flight. The seatbelt sign was illuminated at the time and the pilots did not have any indication of severe turbulence in the area. The flight originally departed Grenada around : AST with  passengers and a crew of five. The Airbus A landed without further incident at : a.m. Eastern Time and taxied safely to the gate. Upon arrival, five passengers were transported to a local hospital to receive medical attention for injuries.Four passengers were treated and released, while one remains for treatment.American has deployed CARE team members to provide support for the injured passengers.Read more

title: nasa images show huge cracks
story: NewsNASA images show huge cracks poised to release iceberg larger than New YorkA Halloween crack has appeared on The Brunt Ice Shelf in the Weddell Sea, Antarctica which is home to the British Halley Research StationShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  FEB NewsThe Brunt Ice Shelf is a  foot-thick sheet of ice in the Weddell Sea "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An iceberg twice the size of New York City is about to break off from Antarcticas Brunt Ice Shelf, according to NASA .The space agency released aerial images which show massive cracks along the frozen landscape that have been growing since October .Once the cracks meet, the outer ice is expected to completely snap off and float away, reports Newsweek .The Brunt Ice Shelf is a  foot-thick sheet of ice in the Weddell Sea which was home to the British Halley Research StationHowever since the broken ice, known as the Halloween crack, first appeared inlate October  the research station has had to be relocated over the last few years.Scientists have been closely monitoring the growth of the crack through satellite imagery and now NASA say it is the countdown to calving afteranother massive chasm started growing in the area. Ice calving is where an iceberg breaks away from the edge of a larger body of ice is is a natural process that regularly happens. Another recent example was the  calving of a Delaware-sized iceberg from the Larsen C ice shelf that broke away from the Antarctic Peninsula.   But the calving at Antarctica’s Brunt Ice Shelf is unusual as NASA say that the region was originally thought of as stable. However the crack has been growing at a rate of around . miles per year. Pictures from NASAs Operational Land Imager show how the crack has grown eastwards from an area dubbed the McDonald Ice Rumples. In a statement, the space agency said: It is not yet clear how the remaining ice shelf will respond following the break, posing an uncertain future for scientic infrastructure and a human presence on the shelf that was first established in .  “The rumples are due to the way ice flows over an underwater formation, where the bedrock rises high enough to reach into the underside of the ice shelf. “This rocky formation impedes the flow of ice and causes pressure waves, crevasses, and rts to form at the surface.” The latest crack has led to concerns about the Halley Research Station, which is run by the British Antarctic Survey. Usually the base runs year-round, but the “unpredictable changes” to the ice has meant it has had to shut down twice over the last few years.   Chris Shuman, a glaciologist with NASA, said in a statement: “The likely future loss of the ice on the other side of the Halloween Crack suggests that more instability is possible, with associated risk to Halley VI.”A spokesperson from the BAS told Newsweek that the safety of its staff is the top priority and they are constantly monitoring the movement of the ice.She said: Our most recenthigh-resolution synthetic aperture radar image showed that the rate of widening of the crack does appear to have increased since mid-January, but not enough to cause alarm, she said. The station is designed to be relocatable. In  BAS successfully relocated the station’s eight modules kmupstream of a previously dormant ice chasm. The frequency of relocation depends very much on how the ice behaves in the future. Our long-term ice monitoring project is designed to alert us of any signicant change in the ice.

title: violent clashes venezuela border sees
story: NewsViolent clashes at Venezuela border sees troops shoot four dead and wound Venezuelan civilians were shot by forces loyal to Maduro at the Colombian-Brazilian border after he ordered them to block humanitarian aidShareCommentsByRachel Endley :,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video venezuelan-military-uses-tear-gas-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt least four people have been killed and  injured amid violent clashes in Venezuela. Violent scenes saw forces loyal to Nicolaacutes Maduro open fire at the Colombian-Brazilian border after the president ordered them to block humanitarian aid entering the country.In Santa Elena de Guairen four people were shot dead and  injured after irregular pro-government militias known as colectivos opened fire, according to Foro Penal, a legal non-profit group that tracks violence in Venezuela.The group’s director, Alfredo Romero said: “We’ve been told colectivos shot at people at the border and the situation is grave. Shocking security footage taken at the Venezula-Colombia border shows chaos at Francisco de Paula Santander bridge as people scrambled to grab supplies from a truck while Venezuelan riot police shot tear gas at them.   Demonstrators clashed with Venezuelas security forces at the bridge, near the town of Urena, Venezuela, which was one of three across which Guaido was hoping to pass much-needed food and medicine. Medics were also treated civilians near the Simoacuten Boliacute for tear gas inhalation and injuries sustained following a stampede that retreated when canisters were fired. The clashes came after Venezuelas opposition and activists confronted troops stationed along the countrys borders to block their plan to bring in food and medicine that authorities are calling a veiled U.S.-backed invasion. Juan Guaido declared himself interim successor to President Maduro in the face of a crisis that has led millions to flee and left hundreds of thousands hungry.  While the need for basic food and medicines is real - with the countrys inflation running at more than  million percent per year - the effort is also meant to embarrass military officers who continue to support Maduros increasingly isolated government. Maduro said today that his government had broken relations with Colombia and he would expel some Colombian diplomatic staff after Colombia assisted the oppositions efforts to bring humanitarian aid into the country. He said in a speech: Patience is exhausted, I cant bare it anymore, we cant keep putting up with Colombian territory being used for attacks against Venezuela. For that reason, I have decided to break all political and diplomatic relations with Colombias fascist government.  He said the ambassador and consular staff would have to leave Venezuela within  hours. Guaido, recognized by most Western nations as the countrys legitimate head of state, defied court orders not to leave Venezuela by arriving on Friday in the Colombian border city of Cucuta, where aid from the U.S. and Colombian governments is stockpiled in warehouses. Today the obstacles that the dictatorship created will tomorrow be rivers of unity, of peace, Guaido said in a news conference in Cucuta, where he was received by Colombian President Ivan Duque. Vice President Delcy Rodriguez said in a tweet late on Friday that Venezuelas government shut the Tachira border that connects it with Cucuta temporarily due to a series of illegal threats by Colombia. A group of frustrated Venezuelans who were seeking to cross into Colombia on Saturday to work morning threw rocks and bottles at National Guard troops, who responded with tear gas.  We were all going to work, we want to work, the people attempted to force through, said Viviana Meza, , who works in a Cucuta restaurant. At least four National Guard officers on Saturday at the border disavowed Maduros government and requested assistance from the Colombian government, Colombias migration agency said on Saturday. Maduro blames the countrys dire situation on U.S. sanctions that have blocked the country from obtaining financing and have hobbled the OPEC nations oil industry. Rodriguez says the aid is poisoned. I dont plan to leave my house over the weekend, especially after what happened near Brazil, said Paulina Sanchez, a -year-old grandmother who lives just  metersfrom the Francisco de Paula Santander bridge.  This could turn into a powder keg. In a slightly surreal twist Guiado and Maduro held opposing concerts just  yards apart on either end of a bridge linking Colombia and Venezuela. The battle of the bands pits Venezuela Live Aid organised by British billionaire Richard Branson, against Maduros Hands Off Venezuela festival. Branson,after being approached by Guaido, is bidding to raise million in donations through Venezuela Aid Live on the Colombian side ofTienditas bridge. On the other side of the crossing, closed off with freight containers, President Nicolas Maduro will hold hands off Venezuela - a three day festival. Guaido in January invoked articles of the constitution to assume interim presidency and denounced Maduro as a usurper, arguing his  re-election was illegitimate.

title: curran an injury worry for dundee ahead of hibs clash on friday
story: Craig Curran is Dundee’s major fitness doubt for their Friday night clash with Hibs at Dens Park.The former Dundee United and Ross County striker played at Livingston last weekend but has been nursing a stomach problem since the draw with Kilmarnock a fortnight ago.He hardly trained last week and has been missing again over the past few days.“Craig is very sore, he didn’t train all last week because of a stomach thing,” said boss Jim McIntyre.“He’s going to require a few days to get over it.”If it’s a case of wait and see with Curran, Jim is confident both Andrew Nelson and Andreas Hadenius will make it.Nelson had to come off after netting the equaliser at Livi when he aggrevated ankle and calf problems as he celebrated his goal.And Swede Hadenius was replaced early in the second half at the weekend after picking up a knock.Both, though, have responded to treatment and are expected to be fit for Friday.With four goals since his arrival from Sunderland last month, -year-old Nelson is the man of the moment at Dens.While the manager stresses the young attacker remains a work in progress, he’s been delighted with his performances so far.“Nelson is a goalscorer and I thought his finish at the weekend was excellent,” Jim added.“It looked ashe was stretching but he’s managed to generate it into the corner.“As I’ve said before, he is raw. He still needs a lot of work, working with a partner and when to link and stuff but I’m delighted with his goals contribution so far.”

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he’ll be putting out means he’s not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he’s not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.“I don’t know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. It’s going to be a tough game,” said Jim.“He’s got good options as well, you need to be able to handle that.“We know what players he’s got to work with and we know their strengths and weaknesses like we do most of the other squads in the league. It’s about making sure yours are better than theirs on the night, that’s how it is in football.“We are back at home in front of the cameras and want to put on a good performance.”Dundee go into the game boosted by last week’s vital win at Livingston that hauled them out of the bottom two in the top flight for the first time since late August.Again, though, the manager is stressing it’s where the team are at the end of the season that counts.“We could be back down there come Saturdaywe don’t keep it going.“Livingston is gone now and now it’s all about this one.”

title: family pays tribute to dundee guitarist kenny whose music took him all over the world
story: The family of a popular Dundee musician have led tributes to the talented guitarist following his death at the age of .Kenny Day died last weekend having spent the last years of his le living with dementia.A well-known figure on the Dundee music scene, Kenny, from Lochee, played in bands such as The Bad Pennies, Ringer and Sanjo during the s and s.His touring career took him across Scotland and the world where he performed in Germany and New York.Kenny’s son, Kenneth Day Jr, said: “It didn’t matter what it was – everything was a joke to my dad.“I remember his car broke down one night in Germany and he managed to fix the fan belt with women’s tights which were in the car.“A few months later he was still driving around with the tights connected to the fan belt.“He liked the women too. He had all the ladies around him. Even in the care home, he was a charmer.”His daughter, Jackie, , from Fintry, said: “I want people to know how talented he was – music was his le.“He first started out at about age four when he sang on stage with his sister Wilma but he first picked up a guitar at age  and I’m not surehe stole his older brother’s guitar.”Jackie said her father had a wide taste in music, although The Beatles were his favourite and his band Ringer would often cover songs by the Fab Four.Kenneth, , from Menzieshill, said he was inspired to take up guitar by his father.He said: “He would always ask me, ‘which Beatles song are we going to learn this week ’“I play in a band now and took it from my dad. People know my dad – after I put it on Facebook I’ve just had loads of comments with people saying that my dad was like a mentor to them.“Some musicians have been in touch to say my dad taught them how to play.”Kenny’s elder sister, Phyllis Duffin, , from Craigiebank, said his talents went beyond his musical knowledge, adding: “He had learnt six languages from French, Spanish, Urdu to Polish. He was very talented but had no common sense.“He loved going to Campbeltown in the west of Scotland to visit his cousins. I remember phoning through at one point and his cousin telling me he had been chasing their car in a Wombles suit!”Kenny, who was the youngest of four siblings, was diagnosed with dementia in his early s and entered a care home.Jackie said: “He would forget lyrics, it’s like he was fading away. It was a horrible thing to watch.“It was hard for him, he couldn’t drive anymore but he knew what was ahead. He developed a stammer and got frustrated.”Kenneth said: “Dad was a smart man so it was heartbreaking to see him getting ill.“The other week we were all sitting round him and he hadn’t spoken in over two years but then he began blethering and singing in German.“I told my sister that dad was talking and then he recognised Phyllis when she came in.“His music was playing in the hospital room and my sister turned down the stereo.“Dad said, ‘don’t do that again’ – it was braw!”

title: shoppers complain of dundee post office mess as refurbishment is postponed
story: A Broughty Ferry Post Office has had its refurbishment delayed despite complaints of it being littered with “mess”.The Gray Street branch was originally going to close from February  to March  to be given a makeover but residents have now been told the refurbishment has been postponed “indefinitely”.Christine Kenny, from Broughty Ferry, regularly uses the branch.She said: “The condition of the Post Office is a disgrace, with quite a bit of litter around.“There are bags of rubbish dumped in the front shop.”She added: “It was to be refurbished, but when I was in today the assistant mentioned it has been postponed.“The Post Office should have a say about its condition.“Even a brush, cloth or duster wouldn’t go amiss.”Ferry councillor Craig Duncan spoke of the store’s condition, saying: “The refurbishment has been deferred by the postmaster rather than the Post Office. In a way it’s disappointing but it helps in the short term because the Barnhill Post Office remains closed due to fire damage.”He added: “A lot of these matters are down to the postmaster rather than the Post Office to deal with.“I understand the purpose of the refurbishment is to bring these things up to spec and I welcome that and it will happen at some point. It’s a sizeable building and most of the floor space is not being used at the moment.”“We don’t have a timescale for the works to be done but I’ll find out more in the next two to three months.“As soon as I am aware, I will make that public.”In a statement, the Post Office thanked the Tele for bringing the state of the store to their attention and said the postmaster will be contacted regarding the concerns.Postal services at the Barnhill office on Nursery Road have been closed since a fire at the MS News shop on October .The fire caused almost £, worth of damage, closing the store “indefinitely”.The Gray Street shop was closed in January last year until July, so the store could be made more modern.After the last refurbishment, the store had four serving positions on a modern-screened counter, two open-plan positions and a serving point at the retail section.The opening hours also increased by  hours a week, to operate from am-.pm.

title: tom duthie deeiy sos then dundee boss jim mcintyre is the man to call
story: Rather understandably, no one has asked Jim McIntyrehe’s a fan of the hit BBC show DIY SOS.Perhaps we should, becausehe leads Dundee to safety this season he might just be able to lay claim to being the Scottish Premiership’s version of its presenter Nick Knowles.For those lucky enough to watch only football on the box, it’s the one where Knowles and a team of tradesmen step in to help families or groups with building projects they don’t have the knowhow or resources to complete on their own. To add to the drama, it’s done as a race against the clock.And McIntyre is gaining a growing reputation for doing the same with top-flight clubs here.Four-and-a-bit years ago he arrived at Ross County with the Highland outfit seemingly already doomed to relegation.By the end of that season he hadn’t just kept the Staggies up, he’d rebuilt them into a squad that would go on and win silverware in the shape of the  League Cup.After the Dark Blues’ weekend win at Livingston got them out of the bottom two for the first time since the end of August, thanks to goals from new handy men Andrew Nelson and Scott Wright, there are strong signs he can do the same at Dens Park.McIntyre’s reign as Dundee boss started in October when he received an SOS from owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms.After a miserable start to the campaign, the Americans’ dream of cementing their team as a force in the Premiership and, eventually, taking the club to a new stadium looked in danger of crumbling around them.Confirmation of just how dire the need for an emergency rebuild came in his first game in charge when the roof fell in during a - defeat at Livi. It showed how flimsy the foundations of the team were as they collapsed under the weight of the home team’s excellence at set-pieces.Almost exactly four months on and after that second visit to the Tony Macaroni Arena under the new boss, the structure looks much more sound.And it’s all thanks to the kind of speedy reconstruction he undertook at County and of which Knowles and his team would be proud. For the team that ran out against Livi at the weekend bore no resemblance to the one McIntyre had to work with when he first headed there.Not one of the players in the starting XI in October were on from the start this time and of the  who were involved on that first day,  have left the club.Only Kenny Miller, Cammy Kerr and Elliott Parish remain and, of those three, veteran Miller was the sole participant in the vital - victory.For McIntyre, to bring about almost a complete change in such a short space of time has been a gamble, one that will only be confirmed as paying offhis team are still in the Premiership come the end of the season.It’s one, though, that represents his best chance of success and it is very much a case of so far so good.While Dundee under him remain a work in progress, the signs of improvement have been there for all to see.Since the end of the winter break there have been two wins, two draws and just one defeat in five league outings.By some margin that’s been the best run of form in the top flight so far this term.If it continues there is every reason to believe that target of building a team good enough for this level by the end of the season will have been achieved.Andthat is the case, fans will be hoping given more time, the manager will be able to set about putting together something even more impressive for next season and beyond.

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Final page turned for Invernesss Christian bookshop
story: A CHRISTIAN bookshop in Inverness which has served the Highlands for nearly four decades will soon be closing.The CLCbook-shop in Castle Street provides literature from a Christian viewpoint to local churches and has been a resource centre for the wider community.CLC is a charity which started in Colchester in  and has been operating in Inverness for about  years.Prior to its move to Castle Street about eight years ago the shop was located in Church Street.Shop manager Pam Kerr said the closure decision follows a dropping off in customer footfall.ldquoItrsquos sad because as well as being a valuable resource centre for the Christian community it was a very popular place for people to come in for a coffee and to enjoy some fellowship, she said, adding that its resources will continue to be sold online.Miss Kerr, who is a member of the Inverness Christian Fellowship which meets at Merkinch Community Centre every Sunday, said that although the shop was closing an exact date would depend on how soon someone is found to take over the lease.ldquoCLC has been in Inverness for nearly  years and I have been the manager of the shop since it moved to Castle Street, she said.ldquoAs well as providing resources for local churches and the Christian community we supply to places like Wick, Thurso, Ullapool and Skye.ldquoBefore the shop opened here in Inverness CLC had a van which travelled from Aberdeen supplying local churches and the Christian community and attended local fairs and shows where it ran stalls.The specialist chain provides books and resources, including films, music and seasonal gts.The closure is just the latest in Castle Street where Tomlinsons Beer Shop closed in August last year after six years in business.It was closely followed by the closure of the CoolNess ice cream parlour on the site of the former Nessiersquos Arcade.Agents for the owners reported the business had been ldquobarely breaking even.Mike Smith, manager of Inverness Business Improvement District previously said the closure was ldquounfortunate but hoped a new tenant would be found soon for a business that was ldquowell fitted out.This week signs outside the parlour suggested the site is currently under offer.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness Airport travel figures on the rise
story: Inverness Airport has continued to have a rise in passengers with an increase of . per cent, up to , travellers, in .However, overall figures from Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd , show a minor drop of . per cent in passenger figures across the  airport network.In  ,,passengers use Hial airports, compared with ,, in , with Barra, Campbeltown, Dundee and Wick all having slight drops in passenger journeys.Sumburgh in Shetland had the biggest fall of . per cent, largely due to a change to helicopter operations in the oil and gas sector.Hial managing director Inglis Lyon said: ldquoThe overall figures illustrate the need for continued investment and support in regional airports that offer connectivity for the communities they serve.ldquoInverness Airport continues to grow and is playing an ever more important role in improving connectivity to and from the Highlands.Its international connections and regular flights to hub airports in Amsterdam, London and Dublin make it an attractive proposition for travellers.That growth could continue this year when BA starts its double daily flights between Inverness and Heathrow and KLM introduced three flights per day on its Amsterdam service for the summer season.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: shinnie double secures seventh straight away win for aberdeen
story: ABERDEEN secured a seventh straight away victory as skipper Graeme Shinnie fired a devastating double to dump St Johnstone - in Perth.Club captain Shinnie netted superb goals either side of the break to move the Dons to within two points of second placed Rangers who are in action tomorrow.Aberdeen made two changes to the side held - at home to Premiership bottom club St Mirren.last weekend.Dom Ball came in for Tommie Hoban who suffered a season ending cruciate ligament injury against the Buddies at the weekend.Hoban, who was on loan from Premier League Watford, will undergo surgery.Also coming into the starting line-up was Connor McLennan with Niall McGinn dropping to the bench.Ball went into the right back position normally occupied by Shaleum Logan who it has been confirmed will undergo surgery on an ankle injury and could be ruled out for the season.On loan Rotherham defender Ball impressed in the right-back role.Aberdeen grabbed the lead in the th minute when Ball stole the ball off Kennedy before sliding a pass to Graeme SHINNIE.Scotland international Shinnie cut past Sean Goss before unleashing a precision right footed shot past Cammy Bell from the edge of the penalty area.It was a quality finish from Shinnie, who is out of contract at the end of the season and has yet to make a decision on his future.Aberdeen have offered Shinnie a lucrative new contract but the Pittodrie club remain in limbo..Shinnie was again at the heart of the action in the st minute to recover a precarious situation for Aberdeen as on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe lost possession in the St Johnstone half when pushing forward.It created a hole at the back that Goss exploited with a superb cross field ball flighted in behind the fractured rear-guard to release Chris Kane in on goal.Just as he was about to shoot from  yards out Shinnie made up vital ground before pitching in with a tackle to dispossess him.In the th minute Aberdeen were denied when Gary Mackay-Steven met a McLennan cross to unleash a  footed right footed volley that keeper Bell blocked.Moments later Dons keeper Joe Lewis was called into action as he tipped a  yard header from Murray Davidson over the bar.In the th minute teenager Lewis Ferguson, who this week signed a two year contract extension until , fired a powerful  yard drive across the face of goal and just wide.Aberdeen should have increased their advantage in the th minute when Shinnie burst into the box to collect a pass from Stewart before crossing low to find McLennan in space.However the winger, back into the starting line up, blasted over from  yards.The woodwork denied Saints in the th minute when a drilled cross from Kennedy came off the outstretched boot of Mikey Devlin and cracked off the post.Captain SHINNIE netted his second goal to make the three points safe when he won the ball on the half-way line before powering up-field.Shinnie then unleashed a superb left footed  yard drive beyond keeper Bell.ABERDEEN: Lewis, Ball, Devlin, Considine, Lowe, Ferguson, Shinnie, Stewart, Mackay-Steven, McLennan, Cosgrove.Subs: McGinn , May , Gleeson .Subs not used: Cerny, Virtanen, Campbell, WilsonST title: bid chiefs vision gets msp seal of approval
story: An Aberdeen business chief has met a cabinet secretary to promote the importance of business improvement districts.Aberdeen Inspired represents more than  businesses who pay a levy which helps fund improvements across the city centre.The newly-formed Scottish City BIDs Group met Aileen Campbell MSP, the Cabinet Secretary for Communities and Local Government, this week.Business rates and a tourism levy were among the issues discussed during the meeting in Edinburgh.The meeting saw Allan Henderson, chairman of Aberdeen Inspired, acting as chair, and the body’s chief executive, Adrian Watson, as vice-chair.The Scottish City BIDs Group was established to progress the strategic objectives of the Business Improvement Districtsin cities across the country.Issues discussed included the effect off the current structure of business rates on firms and the potential of a tourism levy and how this may be implemented locally.Mr Watson, who is also vice-chair of the Scottish City BIDs Group, said: “We are grateful to the Cabinet Secretary for her input into the newly formed Scottish City BIDs Group.“In many ways Scotland is ahead in the placemaking agenda, but it was felt this position could be re-enforced with the city BIDs coming together to collectively look to influence policy-makers at a local national level.“Along with this there is the aim of sharing good practice, of which there is plenty, looking at the economy of scale in procuring goods and services and generally furthering the Scottish urban BID agenda.”Meanwhile, Roddy Smith, CEO of Essential Edinburgh, added: “It is so important the city BIDs have this voice.“When you consider the added value that my organisation, Aberdeen Inspired and the other larger BIDs have brought to our Scottish cities, this seems the logical step for us to collectively look at the strategic issues affecting our cities and looking at ways to make progress on them.”

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

It is the time of Lent: the old Germanic word for spring-time. The poems have been chosen are in a beautul book, entitled The Heart’s Time, by Janet Morley. The poems come from across the English-speaking world, over the last four centuries. One poem is set for each day, accompanied by a short explanation, a reflection, and a brief suggestion for our own thinking.Parishoners will be reading the poems at home for those who wish it there will be meetings to share thoughts and inspiration at Ardrishaig Church during the weeks of Lent and at Christ Church on Sundays. Other meetings could be arranged, formally or informally.You can order the book from Fr Simon Mackenzie by emailing dr.lachlan@zen or calling  , or directly from Argyll Book Centre. Lent begins this year on Ash Wednesday March .Lynx reintroduced to Argyll and ButeFollowing on from an announcement that they were surveying Scotland in late , the Lynx UK Trust have identied three locations which could act as release sites for the medium-sized cats, including the Kintyre peninsula.Independent scientic research has shown that Scotland#s forest could sustain around  of the cats, which ecologists believe could help control the UK#s over-populated deer herds, leading to a regeneration of forest ecosystems that would benefit all of the UK#s native wildle.No lynx attack on a human has ever been recorded anywhere, though lynx reintroduction is a controversial issue with sheep farming unions concerned that the cats would decimate herds, though numerous independent studies make clear that sheep are an exceptionally rare target for lynx, even when the two live side by side.A public drop in consultation is scheduled for Tuesday March  from pm to pm in Tarbert village hall.E.ON donated to Arrochar roof insulationVehicles used by the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team will benefit from being garaged at a more constant temperature this winter after the E.ON Energising Communities Fund paid for £, worth of insulation to be fitted at the rescue post.The volunteers making up the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team provide search and rescue assistance throughout Strathclyde when requested by Police Scotland and can be called upon  hours a day,  days a year.  Working across all mountainous terrain and in any weather condition, they use three vehicles which are kept in the garage attached to the mountain rescue post in Arrochar which was built in .After mechanics identied condensation and corrosion as the cause of the vehicles’ increasingly frequent and expensive mechanical and electrical problems, heating was installed at the garage last year to reduce their maintenance costs and improve their reliability. It was then realised that roof insulation was necessary to lower the cost of the heating.Douglas Philp, team secretary for Arrochar Mountain Rescue, said: #As a charity, we’re totally dependent on donations, grants and volunteers. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

story: NewsBlooming marvellous as Ayr flower show sIt promises to be the biggest yet, with more classes and more entertainment.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsTop team Chairman Tom Brown and Secretary Irene Yuill "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe third Ayr and District Flower Show will be back at Ayr Racecourse in August. It promises to be the biggest yet, with more classes and more entertainment. It is being switched this year to a Friday and Saturday to avoid a clash with the Sunday market. Ticket prices will remain the same at just pound and under-s free, new secretary Irene Yuill revealed. The experienced administrator, now retired from Auchincruive College, has been drafted in to assist chairman Tom Brown and the committee of volunteers. The show will be staged on August  and . Secretary Irene revealed winners will not get a prize money cannot buy and added: “Adults will no longer get money for winning classes. Instead they will get a fine crystal keepsake. This will be engraved and presented for the best exhibit in each section.” New classes will be introduced for the first time this year including Handicrafts, Baking, Preserves and Walking Sticks. Lego Models and a Miniature Garden in a seed tray will be added to the junior section. All classes will be FREE to enter.   There will be a wide range of trade stands including some craft stalls. Ayr Racecourse will again run a Food Market in the Princess Suite. There will be Cookery and Floral Demonstrations. Irene added: “For the first time this year we will be joined by the Model Railway Club who will set up a display and musical entertainment will be on offer.” The organisers are looking for as many volunteers to help, including stewarding and unseen work in the background such as stage building and dismantling. Chairman Tom Brown said: “To run the show we rely on the good will of the many volunteers who give up their time. We must thank everyone who has helped make Ayr  District Flower Show the success it has been over the last two years and hope we can count on their support again this year. “It is a great family day out with something for everyone to enjoy.” *Enlist your help by mailing ayranddistrictflowershow@gmail or  .

title: malawi partners set top tour
story: NewsMalawi partners get set for top tour of AyrshireErnest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - .ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB NewsFrancis Juma with Bill Duncan, Elder from Alloway Parish Church "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlloway Parish Church are gearing up to welcome partnering head teachers from across the globe next month. Following the success of the Alloway Malawi Mission , the church, in partnership with Alloway and Doonfoot Primary Schools have invited two head teachers from their partner schools in northern Malawi to visit Ayrshire in March. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - . A full itinerary has been organised including working with and observing the teachers and head teachers across local schools including Belmont Academy and Wellington School. Visits to Culzean Castle and Ayr Hospital have also been arranged.   The duo are very excited to meet the Provost and the Director of Lelong Learning of South Ayrshire Council. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma will attend worship at Alloway Parish Church on both Sundays, and will join families at Messy Church on March . And a fun-filled community “Scottish Night” with ceilidh dancing, entertainment and a quiz will be held in the church halls on Saturday, March  from . – pm, to really make the visitors welcome. Alloway and Doonfoot pupils are very excited to meet the head teachers and to learn more about their friends from Malawi. Mr Juma and Mr Chirwa will also be able to attend the wonderful Pop UK recording, with concerts set to be held in the church on March . And will be able to take back photographs and videos to share with their pupils, as well as a copy of the CD recorded by Alloway youngsters to share with their schools, church and communities.

title: scots skating star set follow
story: NewsScots skating star set to follow Dancing on Ice heroes Torvill and DeanPrestwick lad Lewis Gibson is being touted as the next big thing in British ice dance and has his sights set on the next Winter Olympics in Beijing.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA skating star who caught the ice bug while watching telly is being primed for a shot at the Olympics. Prestwick lad Lewis Gibson and his London dance partner Lilah Fear are on course to become Britain’s next Torvill and Dean. The duo are hotly tipped to melt the cold stuff en route to Beijing in . As the nation’s next big thing they are now locked away in a Canadian training camp. And Lewis’ proud parents reckon the former Prestwick Academy kid can overcome his status as a late starter. Mum Shirley, , revealed: “He was sat on the couch one night watching ‘Dancing On Ice’ and became hooked.  “But he was  by then, which is very late to start when you consider most of the world-class skatersare on the ice from when they can walk.“He just decided that was the sport for him and, all credit to him, he’s making a real go of it.” Dad Mark, , added: “Ice dance isn’t the most popular sport among teenage lads but he was determined to have a go and it’s paid off. “He and Lilah go to the world championships in Japan next month and they’re hoping for a really good showing. “They’re already developing a very good following across the world. title: taking look back ayr high
story: NewsTaking a look back at Ayr High Streets changing styleBack in , the Auld Toun was saying farewell to J Thomson  Son – a business which had been founded in the s.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsHats fill a window at J Thomson  Son, gents’ outfitters "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Ayr High Street faces up to an uncertain future, it’s worth looking back on an earlier break with the past, writes Edwin Lawrence. Back in , the Auld Toun was saying farewell to J Thomson  Son – a business which had been founded in the s. The shop was taken over to make way for the giant Buttermarket development that saw British Home Stores move in. Ironically, BHS has now also gone, and that part of the town must again try to re-invent itself. Joan Kirk, , provides us with a link back to Thomsons’ wonderful shop.  For in  she was Mrs Thomson, and husband Gilbert was the third generation in his family to run the business. Mrs Kirk recalls: “Other old-established clothing businesses had closed by then, but Gilbert kept profit margins low to stay competitive. “However, BHS made him an offer he couldn’t refuse. “It was perhaps a blessing in disguise, as I got to spend time with Gilbert before he died in , aged .”  Mrs Kirk later remarried but has been widowed for a second time. The young Joan had come to Ayr in  from Lochmaben, Dumfriesshire, to train as a nurse. She later met dashing young shop owner Gilbert, and the pair were married, going on to have a son and daughter. Hats were a signicant part of the Thomson business when Gilbert’s grandfather opened the shop in Victorian times. A large top hat is clearly visible above the front door in the old photo.

title: volunteers bid breathe new life
story: NewsVolunteers bid to breathe new le into Ayr town centre with arts hubThe team behind the move say they will bring fresh ideas and creation to the towns bottom end.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bid to breathe new le into Ayr’s emptying High Street will be staged by hard working volunteers. The group insist a “cultural hub” can spark much needed footfall at the town’s tired bottom end. And they hope a plan to rent the former clothing store, Millets, will aid their cause. FreshAyr, the team behind the project, are not new to opening ‘pop-up’ spaces in the town. But boss Robert Singer, , insists: “We believe this next phase is potentially our most important. “Ayr has lost its place as a market town and tourist destination. “Long gone are the factories, fisheries and agricultural markets of the past – even retail is failing. “So there is a serious pressing need to rethink the way people engage with High Streets. “Our project will focus on the arts and use it as a force for regeneration.” The team have won a three month ‘proof of cause’ deal which, they hope, will lead in turn to later funding.   Robert explained: “We have a five year project in mind with this unit ideally being our permanent base. “Until now, we have operated around the town on a pop-up basis but that is never ideal. “We’d like this as our home.” The ‘BREAD arts lab’ will launch next month and run in conjunction with the project’s bakehouse, which is set to operate from Cathcart Street. Robert said: “We want people to engage with the process...to come in and literally see bread being made before their eyes before taking it home. “At our High Street base we will stage exhibitions, performances, music and art. “We want this to be a centre for everything creative.” •What is your view  Send us your opinion by email on news@ayrshirepost or give us a call on  .Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr News

title: watch-virtual-tour-of-new-jedburgh-campus-ahead-of-public-open-day
story: BORDERERS are being invited to see howJedburghs new school is progressing.Work began on the pound million intergenerational campus last summer.And on Thursday, March  an open day will be held at the site.Leader of Scottish Borders Council Shona Haslam said: ldquoThere is real excitement building as we approach one year until the new Jedburgh campus opens.ldquoEngagement with the people of Jedburgh has been key to this project since its inception, and is continuing with the upcoming Open Doors Day event and the information session taking place for community groups, alongside the ongoing consultation to provide a name for the new campus.ldquoWe are determined to continue to improve our school estate to ensure it is fit for purpose for our young people, staff and local communities.The new campus at Hartrigge Park will replace Jedburgh Grammar, Howdenburn and Parkside primary schools.And it will have provision for nursery, primary and secondary school children while community facilities will include a multi-use games area, G hockey pitch, G sports pitch, running track, external changing pavilion and rural skills area.Councillor Carol Hamilton, SBCrsquos executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoI would encourage the local community to find out more and get involved in the events being held in the coming weeks and months.ldquoFor those who cannot make the Open Doors Day, we have provided a virtual tour of the exterior of the building on social media, and will be adding another of the inside of the building in the coming weeks.ldquoExcellent progress is being made with construction of the campus, which means it remains on course to open to Jedburghrsquos young people and the community in spring .Bruce Dickson, of contractors BAM Construction, added: ldquoAs members of BuildUK, we fully support Open Doors Day which is designed to change the public perception of the construction industry and what we do.ldquoJedburgh Campus is perfect for this, being both a landmark community building in terms of design and purpose and also an exemplar construction site run by a superb team.ldquoWe hope that all of our visitors will get an
